Although they won't travel this year due to the pandemic, Akruti and her family have planned a smaller celebration at home, and plan to drop off goodies to local friends and family to continue teaching the younger generation about Diwali. #HappyDiwali #communitybank 8/8 https://t.co/SJsFMff3lV

During #Diwali, observers pray, exchange gifts, enjoy traditional foods, show gratitude & wish prosperity to friends and family. She’s even created a customizable “Diwali box” for kids which includes books, postcards, stickers. 7/
Akruti describes #Diwali as a "mixture of Thanksgiving and Christmas with a focus on family and spending time together, and signifies the victory of good over evil.” 6/

Prior to the pandemic, Akruti kept busy by teaching educational workshops at museums, schools and libraries. When things began to close, she lost big chunk of revenue, but was able to pivot to create her newest project, a 32 inch in diameter floor puzzle. https://t.co/TkXWbnSD86

After much consideration, she made the decision to quit her full-time position to devote her time to gathering the resources needed to start a business that would allow her to share her culture with the world, and @Kulture_Khazana was born.

Akruti was enjoying a successful career as a project manager when her son – now three – was born. After his arrival it became even more critical to preserve the cultural traditions she grew up with for future generations. 3/

Akruti immigrated from Surat, India to the U.S. 20 years ago with her parents. This self-proclaimed 'momprenuer' built her business in part because of her desire to pass her heritage on to her son. 2/

“I've never been prouder to work for this organization. I think M&T has done a wonderful job with the pandemic. Whether it’s a disability or a challenge with kids/family obligations, there is no one size fits all approach. They care.” #communitybank #NDEAM2020 #inclusion 10/10

Of her experience at the bank, Amy says that she's able to bring her authentic self to M&T. "Leveraging self-identification has been critical to my success. My manager knows, and I'm very open and communicative about my issues and concerns." 9/10

Prior to the pandemic, Amy had a workplace accommodation that allowed her to work from home three days a week. "My manager has been wonderful. When planning seating at our new office space at Seneca One, she reached out to ask, ‘how can I help.’" 8/10

"DAN is a forum for people who self-identify as disabled, take care of children with disabilities, or are caregivers for adults with disabilities. We hold a "Share a Story" event to offer a safe space for employees. Some have shared their diagnosis for the first time.” 7/10
Amy is on the steering committee of M&T’s Disability Advocacy Network (DAN) Resource group and works to ensure that our decisions are inclusive across the bank. 6/10
"I don't let my disability define me. I am aware of it, I do recognize my restrictions, but I'd never let my situation define me," she says. 5/10

As a result, Amy wears custom-made braces on her ankles for stability. Things like buttoning pants or putting on jewelry can be a struggle. She jokes that as the muscle atrophy affects her foot movement, she's not the typical woman when it comes to buying shoes–she hates it! 4/10

At the age of 40, Amy was diagnosed with the genetic disorder that affects her from the knees and elbows down, causes muscle atrophy, and sensitivity issues. Six years after her diagnosis, Amy was in a serious car accident that further exacerbated her MD. 3/10

Amy Graff, Scrum Master in Credit Risk Oversight, has an uncanny ability to see the positive in most any situation. She’s smart, determined and has high-energy. She also has a rare form of muscular dystrophy (MD). 2/10
To close out #NDEAM2020, check out this profile on our employee, Amy Graff: A thread… 1/10 https://t.co/kWToVYfCcI
